Description: Mould-made scarab in glazed composition; back crudely modelled with simple, deeply marked lines to represent main features: mouth and clypeus distorted by insertion of perforation at angle; side view not known; base featuring deeply stamped (rather than incised) motif arranged vertically representing three hieroglyphic signs: a falcon with sun disc above back, standing on papyriform column (Wadj sign); pierced lengthwise; thick light pale turquoise glaze with yellow glaze within motif (?); buff core.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Falcon, sometimes with a flail or wearing a crown like here, is a recurring motif for various compositions found on scarabs and scaraboids produced at the “Scarab Factory” (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). This scarab belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93-107, type XXVIII A, subtype A140-148, see especially A144b for this piece). The hieroglyphic signs on its underside does not seem to make sense. The hieroglyphs could be used here for their magical value as often for this type of scarab (Gorton 1996, 93). However, the cryptic reading of the name of Amun is another possible interpretation (on the cryptic writing of the name of Amun: Drioton 1957) Drioton, E. 1957, 'Trigrammes d'Amon', Festschrift Hermann Junker zum 80. Geburtstag (Wiener Zeitschrift für die Kunde des Morgenlandes 54), Wien, 11-33. Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1889, Historical scarabs: a series of drawings from the principal collections arranged chronologically, London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
